Package ohos.utils

Class ConditionHelper

  • java.lang.Object
    • ohos.utils.ConditionHelper

  • public class ConditionHelper
extends Object
    A helper class to use the Condition class built in the java.util.concurrent.locks package without processing Lock and java.lang.InterruptedException exceptions.

    The ConditionHelper object provides interfaces for suspending a thread (making it wait) or waking up a waiting thread. It supports infinite wait or timed wait. The thread will not exit the waiting state until it is awakened or the specified waiting time elapses.

    Pay attention to the following when using the ConditionHelper class:

    • If you do not reset the wakeup state after a thread is awakened, the execution result will be returned immediately when you call the ConditionHelper#await or ConditionHelper#await(long awaitMs) method next time.
    • The ConditionHelper#await(long awaitMs) method does not ensure precise timing.
    • If a java.lang.InterruptedException exception occurs during the waiting period, the waiting state does not terminate. After the thread is awakened or the waiting time elapses, you can use Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted() to check whether the thread is interrupted.
    Since:
    1

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description

      A constructor used to create a ConditionHelper instance with the default wakeup state false.

      A constructor used to create a ConditionHelper instance with the specified wakeup state.

      Suspends the current thread until it is awakened.

      Suspends the current thread until it is awakened or the waiting time elapses.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConditionHelper

        public ConditionHelper​()
        A constructor used to create a ConditionHelper instance with the default wakeup state false.

      • ConditionHelper

        public ConditionHelper​(boolean isWakeup)
        A constructor used to create a ConditionHelper instance with the specified wakeup state.
        Parameters:
        isWakeup - Indicates the wakeup state to set. The value true indicates that the thread is awakened, and value false indicates that the thread is not awakened.

    • Method Detail

      • wakeup

        public void wakeup​()
        Wakes up the thread of the current object and sets its wakeup state to true.

        If you do not reset the wakeup state by calling resetCondition(), the execution result will be returned immediately when you call the await() or await(long awaitMs) method next time.

      • resetCondition

        public void resetCondition​()
        Resets the wakeup state back to false, and then you can call await().

      • await

        public void await​()
        Suspends the current thread until it is awakened.

        If the wakeup state of the object is true, the execution result of this method will be returned immediately.

        If a java.lang.InterruptedException exception occurs, the current thread continues to wait until it is awakened. After it is awakened, you can use Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted() to check whether the thread is interrupted.

      • await

        public boolean await​(long awaitMs)
        Suspends the current thread until it is awakened or the waiting time elapses.

        If the wakeup state of the object is true, the execution result of this method will be returned immediately.

        If a java.lang.InterruptedException exception occurs, the current thread continues to wait. After the thread is awakened or the waiting time elapses, you can use Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted() to check whether the thread is interrupted.

        Note that this method does not ensure precise timing because it uses the system clock. The timing precision may be affected if the system clock changes.

        Parameters:
        awaitMs - Indicates the waiting time, in milliseconds. If this parameter is set to 0, the thread keeps waiting.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the thread waits for being awakened; returns false if the thread waits until the waiting time elapses.
